title: Wednesday, 4th July, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Hello! Hi there. Welcome. Good morning.

AAAA bonjour les amis !
Soundbuy Morgen.......
#REF! hi, in the words of the Cbeebies WC song "kicky kicky kick kick"
BE11:05am

Guessing we should mention the football.

pancakes or waffles is it coming home
BE11:06am

A gritty, dogged performance against difficult opposition.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Not glamorous, but job done. It ended Brechin City 0 Dundee United 2.

BE11:07am

https://www.thecou...re-season-victory/

undefined
11:09 am
BE11:09am

So ....... it's July 4th so it's fairly quiet.

BE11:09am

The main focus this morning seems to be TalkTalk.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 108.90, up 4.2 (+4.01%), High: 109.10, Low: 105.00, Volume: 667.90k
11:09 am
BE11:10am

Now leading the FTSE 250, albeit on a somewhat slow reaction to the news that Tosca continues to add to its stake.

Tom Dalgleish Whatabout Cowdenbeath
BE11:10am

https://www.invest...1807040833335561T/

jaws g m
BE11:10am

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Which is interesting mostly because it follows a pattern.

jaws ISAT bit better another rumor? or RBC note move
BE11:11am

Tosca went up from 11% towards the start of last month. https://www.invest...1806111106039756Q/

OnYourRight Morning all
Pharma @pancakes etc. I have one word for you: Betteridge (law of headlines)
StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst Whats the difference b/w stuff on LHS and RHS?
BE11:13am

.... now, one of the interesting sidebars here is that Tosca. as in Martin Hughes backed the take-private of Daisy Group in 2014. https://www.ft.com...-a31b-00144feab7de

11:14 am
BE11:14am

(@StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst: we've been doing this for 12 f____ years. Can I suggest you do a bit of analysing?)

Soundbuy @StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst - we talk about stuff, the chappy on the other side does likewise, occasionally there's some connect............
BE11:15am

That's the same Daisy that recently pulled the plug on the deal to buy TalkTalk's business-to-business stuff.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst Still not getting it.... what am I not analyzing
StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst Who is that chap on LHS and why does he exist?
Dec69 - Skeptic Is it 12 years of FTAV now? do I get a badge?
Plato the Cook @SCTHFA - look which side you're on; start your analysis there
StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst @PtC ok
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE who pulled the plug? Was it TalkTalk, or Daisy?
BE11:17am

(It was by mutual consent, according to the statement, but most people seemed to get the idea that Daisy pulled out because of a sudden change in its circumstances.)

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst the guy on LHS is so cryptic OMG
11:17 am
BE11:17am

......... You'll also remember that Dunstone raised his stake ever closer to the 30% limit earlier this week.

BE11:18am

https://www.invest...1807020700061584T/

Plato the Cook The chap on the LHS is God. His wrath is terrible
Dec69 - Skeptic TalkTalk the bet is on acquisition, but there's something interest @BE
BE11:18am

.... so, what's the plan here?

11:18 am
BE11:18am

That's more than 50% of TalkTalk held between Dunstone, Ross and Tosca.

BE11:20am

Let's say a 30% premium with those three staying put and you'd have a total cost of maybe £600m to take private? Hypothetically, I mean.

cracklenpop Sainsbury's at a 4 yr high yet 1Q lags the sector. Any grey on why?
BE11:20am

Course, if Dunstone as executive chairman bought shares in the open market while investigating a take-private in any serious way, that would likely be a regulatory matter.

Swedish Chef Verse Concepts@standup The man on the left “will fulfill the desire of those who fear Him; He will also hear their cry and will save them”
alewis2005 Morning all
Upaswellasdown morning all, interesting comment on Asos / Crozier - I'd missed that Asos now has bigger cap than M&S
11:21 am
BE11:21am

So ....... if there is a take-private story here, it's probably not for today. But it's certainly an interesting idea for anyone thinking downside protection.

Dec69 - Skeptic haven't TalkTalk divest films to Ratuken ?
undefined
BE11:23am

Okay, what else?

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Sainsbury mentioned earlier. It's rallying a tad on very dull figures.

BE11:24am

Bang in line. There was a little risk around these ones because of recent Kantar data showing Sainsbury doing very very poorly on food sales.

BE11:24am

It's been worst of the big-four for ages.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

So, since poor food was known, the good news is decent non-food.

BE11:25am

Seasonal stuff. Paddling pools and disposable barbecues.

BE11:26am

And the fact that management stick with FY targets is probably the key positive here.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

On Asda, there's nothing new. Savings guidance unchanged.

Dec69 - Skeptic is there anything on CPG Compass Group? Group Finance Chap stepped down...
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 323.90, up 5.3 (+1.66%), High: 325.00, Low: 319.00, Volume: 3.14m
BE11:27am

And you have a split in the market between people who care about grocery trends and people who are playing CMA probabilities for the Asda merger. The latter probably has the whip hand right now.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Here's Kepler.

BE11:28am

At conference call, Sainsbury confirmed consensus for this year. Q1 performance was in line and highlights the continued competitive trading environment. Sainsbury has already secured GBP3.5bn in financing (more than needed in case of higher working capital needs) for the merger with Asda. We continue to like the story due to upside from the Asda merger. Our 345p target price for Sainsbury is based on 6x EV/EBITDA 2020/21E, 6.5x EV/EBITDAR, and a 7% FCF yield (incl. Asda) in year one after the merger.

Dec69 - Skeptic Also, would be interested to see if any analysts have picked up on the Clean Air issues/commentary mentioned in China this morning.
BE11:28am

And SocGen.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

We see no reason for greater optimism on the figures themselves. The planned merger makes sense but the UK CMA competition review will take one year.

BE11:29am

And Barclays.

BE11:29am

Against relatively low expectations, we think the statement was broadly encouraging. With price investment having been made in the core grocery business – and with comps getting somewhat easier in the coming quarters - there is reason to be cautiously optimistic that grocery sales growth may improve from here. The general merchandise picture also appears encouraging, with the fastest sales growth in the last six quarters. Our recent upgrade on Sainsbury was driven very much by the potential synergy opportunity with ASDA rather than the strength of the core business, but this statement leaves us a little more confident on Sainsbury’s underlying health. We reiterate our Overweight stock rating and price target of 375p (albeit we see upside to 400p if the deal happens).

11:29 am
BE11:29am

You get the idea.

Soundbuy CPG Compass Group...........hmmmm..........always fancied them to take SSP Grp back under their wing........
undefined
Excel Developer @comedian: BE has the power to banish you.
BE11:31am

Compass ......

11:30 am
Compass Group PLC (CPG:LSE): Last: 1,593, down 29 (-1.79%), High: 1,613, Low: 1,589, Volume: 819.08k
BE11:31am

Johnny Thomson's off.

Dec69 - Skeptic S'buy, I have a feeling they're going to start a larger expansion program. Johnny was a good guy at Compass so perhaps he's retiring, always expected him to stay, so the departure is odd, maybe planned but I missed it.
Upaswellasdown soundbuy - cousins would never have done it - he was all about managing the people / process. is the new guy a protogé?
BE11:31am

CFO. On his way at the end of the year. And that's very shortly after the departure of Richard Cousins, the CEO.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Credit Suisse says:

BE11:32am

Overall we believe Thomson was well regarded by investors and we would see his departure as suboptimal.

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE is the risk now someone kitchen sinks something. Unless I missed it this wasn't planned.
BE11:32am

"suboptimal".

Dec69 - Skeptic http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-07/03/c_137298879.htm On the Chinese Clean Air Act, apologies @BE no FT coverage on this issue, which if correct will cut forecasts by near 10% in demand terms and also knock on in excess supply.
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Now .... to put this in context, Mr Thomson was widely seen as one of the two candidates for the CEO job.

jaws anything in Oxford Bio OXB please ?
BE11:34am

Dominic Blakemore got it instead.

Excel Developer @Dec 69 : demand for what?
BE11:34am

Plus, at 46, he has time to turn up in the top job somewhere else.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Kean Marden at Jefferies says:

BE11:35am

Compass is currently exiting certain Support Services activities (with up to £1.1-1.2bn annual revenue) and there is debate among investors about whether the group will run-off these contracts or divest. In our view, Johnny’s departure may slightly prolong the exit process which commenced yesterday when Compass sold Bateman Community Living ($70m annual revenue) to Elior for an undisclosed sum.

BE11:35am

And Barclays, which again sees no huge negative.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

We view the news today as a small negative given the experience and quality that Mr. Thomson brought to the role. That said, given Compass’ track record and experience at the senior management levels, we think that the business will not struggle to find a suitable replacement. We think the equity story is unchanged and view Compass as a high quality, long-term compounder offering attractive TSR potential. Compass is our preferred caterer, trading on a 20.9x cal18E P/E, while Sodexo (UW, PT €71) is our least preferred caterer, trading on 17.8x cal18E P/E.

Dec69 - Skeptic metals.
Tom Dalgleish all metals?
BE11:37am

You'd guess Mr Thomson's replacement would be external,. which increases kitchen-sink risks. But with Blakemore already in place for six months, is that a big risk? Dunno.

undefined
11:38 am
BE11:38am

@Dec69, I know literally nothing about the Chinese Clean Air Act.

Dec69 - Skeptic Not just metals, but cement production and plate glass. Anything energy intensive or pollution issues, inc, metals involved in steel production, aluminum and casting metal,
Tom Dalgleish like China has a parliament now?
Excel Developer @Dec 69: ah, so you meant aggregate demand, i.e. macro-economic term.
Dec69 - Skeptic @BE, its something that the supply chain should consider, as certain towns (primary cities/tier1) are being implied as ex-growth. Mandated by Xi-Boss (scuse the pun)
BE11:40am

My automatic response is that China puts out Clean Air Acts about as often as Kingfisher puts out restructuring plans, and they're about as effective every time. But if that's the wrong conclusion to jump to, please fire away.

BE11:40am

In the meantime, we can talk Inmarsat.

11:40 am
Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 528.20, up 16.8 (+3.29%), High: 534.40, Low: 510.20, Volume: 1.11m
Dec69 - Skeptic @Excel, perhaps yes, but also specific to certain producers.
Penny Is Oxford Biomedica a so-called "Punter stock" ?
Alchemy30 morning, looked weak yesterday on vol
BE11:41am

Selloff yesterday on nothing much.

BE11:41am

Rally today on nothing much.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

I think there was an idea going around yesterday that with today being Independence Day, Echostar might move to clarify things early rather than wait for Friday's Panel deadline.

BE11:43am

We've also had a lot of conversations over the past week or two with people familiar with things, who have been keen to leave behind the idea that it's not a must-do deal for Echostar.

nichoman Has Lansdowne (biggest ISAT shareholder I think) said anything ? they can't be too happy with current management
Pseudonym How come the UK PMI's are so disconnected from GDP at the moment?
BE11:43am

Against that, you have analysts saying it's a must-do deal for Echostar.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Wilton Fry at RBC, for instance.

BE11:44am

In our view there is a very high probability that Echostar bids due to: (a) need for speed: delaying by 6 months gains nothing and risks either a White Knight (or other bidder), and/or losing the battle for Ligado by the time Echostar gains control of Inmarsat, (b) regulatory approval: Delaying will not reveal whether regulatory approval will be given, c) positioning: Echostar's convertible position indicates to us a very strong desire to limit leakage in the post acquisition conversion.

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE, I wonder if the Inmarsat bid was to try to close out Ligado, where gossip is they're proposing an offer (please note Gossip) as Ligado would be able to scale up and compete, rather than piggyback off Echo and Dish (as I think they do currently (please check).
BE11:45am

In summary we believe the most likely outcome (c.60% probability) is an initial offer of c.650p, 20% probability of a low-ball (less than 600p) offer and 20% probability of a 'knockout' offer. Whatever the initial offer, we think it will take an offer of at least 750p to gain any board or shareholder approval. Given the political backdrop (sensitive satellite infrastructure) we believe Echostar is likely to need a recommended offer as a hostile bid could allow the company to seek political protection.

jaws Thank you for ISAT info.
Upaswellasdown pls can you ask Rob Smith to update on Rallye? bonds have crashed further in past week
11:46 am
BE11:46am

RBC sees a decent chance that Ligado gains FCC approval and adds that SoftBank is "a very credible bidder"

BE11:47am

There's also a bunch of work on Echostar's purchase of 10.3% of the convertible, which most regular press coverage has ignored weirdly.

BE11:48am

We calculate the change of control provisions mean the adjusted strike price could be as low as c.£3.90 (depending on various factors), while the maximum number of shares rises considerably (from 22.5m to c. 58m, with dilution at (say) £7.50 of c. 50m shares, or c.11%).

GoliathNationalBank I went to a Casino supermarket last week. There were pigeon's siting on the fresh veg. Assume some Funds were in doing DD on Rallye at the same time.
11:48 am
BE11:48am

That's the gist there.

undefined
BE11:49am

(@Upaswellasdown: will do.)

Dec69 - Skeptic @Upaswellasdown, what's the CDS trading at there?
Upaswellasdown thanks for the comment on the convert - that had also intrigued me. assumed it was the CoC ratchet but didn't have the docs. Is it a cheap way of getting hold of stock?
Upaswellasdown (@BE ta)
Bonnemort OT, but last week people were noting queues outside Lidl on a Saturday morning - it's not the food quality, it's the weekend wine discounts - a drinkable Rioja at £2.99 is the lure and they sell out fast.
11:52 am
BE11:52am

.... okay, so what am I missing in Oxford Biomedica?

BE11:52am

Shares unchanged, no news on the tape.

BornCynic Another newspaper having problems making money "Telegraph profits down 50%".
BE11:53am

Peel Hunt had a sector thing out mentioning them yesterday but it was just maintenance research, I think.

GBKrona @BE - whats up with BT? Steadily up
Bonnemort and re TalkTalk, interesting piece on the founder's philanthropy.https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jul/04/lancashire-town-philanthropy-irlam-talktalk-neil-mcarthur
11:54 am
BE11:55am

You have the possibility of OXB-102 in Parkinson's moving into Phase I/II by the end of the year but nothing immediate due in terms of news. So what am I missing?

BE11:55am

Or are you just asking about any random Aim stock these days, ROTR? Because fair enough.

BE11:56am

As for BT ........

11:55 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 228.00, up 5 (+2.24%), High: 228.25, Low: 220.45, Volume: 6.62m
jaws was yo yo yesterday and peel note was there so wonder if you see anything in that note . Thank you.
BE11:56am

Haven't really heard a single explanation for its recent strength, though clearly the management change and the divi promise have triggered a bit of that rerating.

Excel Developer Re cars, does anyone do "Personal Contract Purchase" ? I.e. 0% for 3 years then hand the car back.
BE11:57am

This, from Numis earlier in the week, sets out the regulatory picture.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

In sum (i) Openreach's FTTP rollout continues to accelerate; (ii) Openreach believes it is finding common ground with Ofcom; (iii) AltNets urgently need, among other things, reform of the wayleave regime but disagree with each other over how this should done (so, in the meantime, Openreach can leverage its considerable resources to build a bigger 'first mover' advantage); (iii) Hyperoptic reports higher than expected take-up of both entry-level and top-tier FTTP service (this suggests lower FTTP investment risk for all builders). On our FY19 estimates, BT now trades on 9.3x adjusted P/E (TSR peers: 12.8x); 8.8% underlying FCFE yield (7.3%); 7.1% DPS yield (4.9%).

BE11:59am

If there's anything more racy behind the recent strength, I've not heard it.

undefined
Soundbuy BT - to be fair it has come down a whack.......
Dec69 - Skeptic Cheers BE
Soundbuy Greencore - any further rumblings............?
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Are we done? I think we're done.

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
BE12:02pm

Haven't mentioned Crispin Odey in the Times. https://www.thetim...-af03-7edc8dc9d023

Soundbuy Cheers.............
BE12:02pm

“In my bones I think that this thing will go for at least £18.”

Excel Developer cheers to Bryce. must be tough to be a Scotsman the day after England victory.
12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

"This thing" being Sky.

Upaswellasdown @Excel - I've been told (on here) that the best thing is to buy the car on PCP, get the discount from the financing and then pay it off the next week
Soundbuy @Excel Developer - BE is a man of the world, a man without borders....
Excel Developer @Upaswellasdown: surely borrowing at 0% when inflation is at 2.8% is the right thing to do.
Excel Developer @Upaswellasdown: if you have a lump sum, invest it in the stock market over the 3 years,
BE12:06pm

As for Greencore, there's been a theory going round the market for ages that they rejected some kind of approach. We've no idea whether it's accurate and, even if it were, it would probably be deal archaeology.

Soundbuy Ta............
Upaswellasdown @ Excel D - I'm assuming that 0% does not mean 0% (assuming it's not EUR denominated) as most credit institutions I know aim to make money. Let me know if you work it out
BornCynic The TV engineer was interesting on SKY - his recommendation was not to switch from SKY HD to SKY Q because once you have SKY Q they have got you. They can literally turn your box off - can't do that with the HD box.
BE12:06pm

Anyway. Gone midday. there's some more stuff over here for those who want it: https://www.ft.com...-8e67-1e1a0846c475

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

Ta for joining, ta for the comments. Back tomorrow.

BornCynic The hole idea behind SKY Q is not to enhance your viewing experience but to tie you to SKY.
BE12:07pm

Afternoon all.

BornCynic whole :)
